Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in requiring a psychological report for 'compelling reasons' claims under subsection 108(4) of IRPA
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), subsection 108(4)
Application_Facts: Applicant's refugee claim was dismissed due to lack of psychological evidence under 'compelling reasons'
Decision_Outcome: RAD's decision was unreasonable; judicial review granted
Court_Ruling: Judicial review granted; decision set aside and remitted for re-determination
Defendant_Behavior: RAD required a psychological report not mandated by law
Grounds_for_Claim: Ceased protection claim with alleged compelling reasons
Assessment_Factor: Existence of compelling reasons for exception to ceased protection
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review following dismissal of appeal by RAD
Application_Basis: Exception to cessation under compelling reasons
Relief_Sought: Granting of refugee protection based on compelling reasons
Governing_Rule: Subsection 108(4) allows exceptions if there are compelling reasons; no requirement for psychological reports
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted; matter remitted
Cause_Description: Applicant's refugee claim was dismissed due to lack of psychological evidence under 'compelling reasons'
Evidence_Handling: Requirement of psychological report deemed improper
Legal_Provision_Violated: None found; RAD applied incorrect legal interpretation
Evidence_Assessment: Psychological report not required by law or precedent
Decision_Rationale: Requirement of psychological report contradicts jurisprudence and fetters discretion
